text: The Jewelry District in Downtown L.A. Neon signs splatter light across racks waterfalling with gold. Oddly no one i out and about. Something major happened. Empty sidewalks glisten with glass from bullet shattered windows. Police cars everywhere. Blocking the street. Yellow tape.
ORO FANTASIA -- A jewelry store where four bad guys are trapped. On the phone with the cops. The BARRICADED ROBBER seems cooperative, calm.
We wanna come out. I'll go back to the joint and do my time like a man.
PUSH IN -- A SWAT SNIPER has carefully created a camoufla nest, tucked away, ready.
We afraid to come out. We know you got snipers and helicopters waiting to bust our heads, you know?
(reassuring, paternal) Not gonne happen. Your lives are just as important as the hostages.

Where a SWAT SUBURBAN is parked. Several SWAT OFFICERS, t most highly trained cops on the force, in big vests and helmets, guard the area. World class athletes at the top their game. Six of them pour through an alley, stealthy infiltrators probing cautiously ahead.

Round a dumpster and approach a heavy back door. Years together in the Marines and on L.A.s mean streets have cemented their friendship and they act as one. One is JIM STREET, he looks more skateboarder than cop, indomitably cheerful, he makes everything looks easy. The other is POKER, an ambitious, preppy type from the So (CONTINUED)

They arrive at a formidable gate topped with coils of raz wire, an impassable obstacle. Poker and Street clamber over-it without pause. Amazing. The remamining four SWAT OFFICERS hang back. Among them i HONDO, one gifted SWAT Cop. With years of experience, he' road worn and stronger than spring steel. The guy you wan on your side. The boss of this six man crew is SERGEANT HOWARD.

Street stands guard as Poker picks the lock of the steel door's deadbolt. CLICK. He unlocks it, grinning. Street oils the hinges with WD-40, slowly pulls the door open. Wedging it open with a rubber stop. This reveals @ second door of formidable iron bars. They can hear VOICES.

Beyond the bars, a dark HALLWAY leads to the jewelry stor up front. A SECURITY GUARD with a stomach wound is tied up with duc tape. Ashen from shock, he SEES Poker and Street, pleads for help with his eyes.
Street makes a "Shhh" sign. Undezstood. Street and Poker trade looks. Street's radio earpiece CRACKLES and GARBLES. He speaks against his throat mike.
Say again. More CRACKLES AND GARBLES.
Poker, you get that?
Uh-uh. Radio interference. Street steps into the alley so Hondo can see him, Street and Hondo converse with handsigns. Street returns Poker, still working the lock. (CONTINUED)
Hondo says the Sergeant wants us to pull back. The negotiator is making progress and doesn't. want the suspects spooked.
Holé on. Almost got it. Poker intently picks the lock of the security bars.

The aiz is thick with fear. There are three COUNTER GIRLS who range from stoic to plain scared. The MANAGER is out cold on the floor, pistol whipped, a knot on his temple. BR BARRICADED ROBBER ard three ACCOMPLICES, are trapped. Hardened gangsters, they are oddly calm, fatalistic.
(into phone) I got kids, man. I don't wanna leave no orphans. We're comin' out, boss. ACCOMPLICE 1” You ain't got no kids. The Barricaded Robber covers the phone.
Shut up. I'm buying time, here. Load up your guns. We shootin' our way cut. Get ready to run fast as you can and blast anything moving. His men check their weapons.

ACCOMPLICE 2 removes his mask. Revealing his face to 4 Ccunter Girl whose blindfold he has removed, his intentio are Clearly lascivious. The Barricaded Robber drops the phone and crosses to him, shoves him against the wall.
Idiot. Why'd you do that? Keep your ugly mug covered. He drags his accomplice toward the back, out of earshot. (CONTINUED)
Take that bitch over there and cap her, dog. The Barricaded Robber returns to the phone.
{into phone) Yo, boss. Can we get a pizza up in here? Accomplice 2 drags the Counter Girl down the hallway.
Street and Poker heard everything. They trade alarmed loo Poker works the lock faster.
They're gonna waste her. Street uses an INSPECTION MIRROR to peer down the hallway INSERT -~ INSPECTION MIRROR P.O.V. ACCOMPLICE 1 drags the terrified COUNTER GIRL by her arm.

Street tries the radio. Nothing. No time to think it through. Poker and Street trade looks, reaching a decisio Street grabs the BREACHING SHOTGUN, designed for blasting open doors, strapped to Poker's back.

Knock-knock. He jerks the trigger -- BOOM-KA-BOOM! The compact shotgun fires Shock-lock slugs -- That SHATTER the HINGES. Poker raises a boot and KICKS the door. WHAM! - CLANG! Th two super cops charge inside. / CUT To:

Go. Get outside. She darts out the back door.
As he pulls a flashbang stun grenade from his vest. Pulis the pin and tosses it into the store. BANG! -- Deafening noise, a BLINDING FLASH. CuT To:

The SWAT CAPTAIN, the big boss, sits at his desk, trunk s arms crossed. Sergeant Howard stands by his side like an attack dog. Street is stoic, but hopeful.

Gentlemen, I respect your abilities, you guys ere high performers. But your judgment is low grade at best. Swat can't use people who don't do what they're told. Cut your patches eff. You two are being reassigned to regular patrol. Street looks at the SWAT patch on his shoulder like he'd rather part with his leg.
Be grateful you're not being fired. Sergeant Howard hands them both letters to sign. Poker sh his head in dismay. Street's hopes are dashed. (CONTINUED)

eC) STREET fe Respectfully, sir. Everyone in this PS building knows we did the right thing. ‘ : I have a two foot high stack of thank you letters from that girl's family. The irony isn't lost on the SWAT CAPTAIN.
You two were insubordinate. That is the issue on the table. (a beat) Sometimes doing the right thing isn't doing the right thing.
Sir, we didn't have time to ask "mother may I." The right thing to do was clear and simple from what we saw and heard.
People died.
& The Lad guys died, sir. That woman Y . was about to be executed right in front of us. The Swat Captain stands, leans forward ominously and gets real quiet.
Officer Martin, Officer Street. You don't run Swat. I do. It's that simple. Poker gets a faraway look in his eye. He turns to Street.
Let's go.
Where?
Away from here. Street hesitates. And that smacks of betrayal to Poker. Poker charges out of there. SLAMS the door. ( e SERGEANT HOWARD You better cool him off while he has @ chance. (CONTINUED)
€ QO Yessir. Street quickly exits.
A gloomy rainy day. Poker bursts out the door. Walking angrily across the lot between rows and rows of black and whites. A beat. Street exits the door, catches up.
Hold up, man. Poker turns, vindicated.
I knew you'd come around, brother.
You're punching out? You're walking?
~ . ‘I'm running. I have better thines VO to do than rack up miles on a city of . car. Poker points at a tired broken police cruiser.
Don't bail like this.
We joined LAPD to work Swat. You want to be just another body on the shift, go ahead.
All you know how to do is run jump, fight and shoot. We'll work nights ina fast division. We'll rock the house. . Poker isn't stopping.. Street gets in his face. Where you gonna go?
@ Bali. Australia. Costa Rica. Big ( World. C'mon, let's check it out. Street considers it a beat. Poker hopeful. Then:
No, man. I don't wanna go out there and drift. I did that. It sucks.
I got skills. I'll find a job. Right there, their friendship is over.
Rather reign in hell than serve in heaven.
What's that mean?

It means I won't stay here and be their bitch. (a beat) I'm not a punk like you. Street swings at Poker. Poker retaliates with blocks and punches. They fight in the rain, brutal, animalistic. Tearing thei uniforms, ruining patent leather shoes. This is one aweso fight. Poker gains the upper hand. Gets Street in an armlock. Street pinned, he can do nothing, in agony.

I twist this way, the bone snaps clean. Heals in six weeks. I twist this way ... You'll never be the same. SNAP! -- Poker breaks Street's arm. «Fight over. Poker stands, spits blood. Street clutching his shattered arm i agony.
Better get that looked at.
I will. Poker walking away.
Hey, Poker. Good luck in hell. (CONTINUED)

Street lays on the asphalt, woozy with pain. Uniformed le gather around Street, hands help him up. :

A cold dark night in Vienna. This locals only cafe is qui Some American pop on the juke. JAQUE sits at a table chainsmoking, a typical euro hipste nervously waiting. A door opens. A large man in a suit named GQ gestures him inside. GQ is intimidating, and a bad dresser.
Upon entering Jaque REACTS. - The room is lined with butcher paper. A human body is nea wrapped in the corner. Clinical.

ALEX DE LEON, disheveled, exhausted. A beer and a smoke i his bloody hands. He's oddly charismatic, clearly very shrewd. Leaning against the wall, relaxing after his exertions. He gestures for Jaque to sit on a paper covered chair.
You came here to face me like a man. I respect and appreciate that. Thank you. JAQUE . What can I say, Alex? They say we choose our fates but I never stole from you. My family is my concern now.
There is no threat to them. You are very brave. Alex gets a cell call, checks the number, ignores it. (CONTINUED)
You knew Larry's hand was in my pocket? Jaque nods: yes. Alex notices his nice watch. Gestures fo it, Jaque guiltily hands it over. Alex admires it. GQ approves. Alex puts it on.
How does the money disappear? Where is the break in the chain?
Larry skims the cash in Los Angeles and drives it into Mexico, he has accounts there. I found this out today. To help you.
Thank you, Jaque. Alex likes hurting people, it's hard for him to cut Jaque . some slack.
You earned this. Quick. No pain.
Thank you, Alex. Alex dismissively waves, nods to GQ who raises his pistol Jaque -- POP! Alex crosses to the sink, washes his hands.
Let's go to California. GQ reacts. .
We might not come back. ALEX . Buy some bulletproof passports. I have to take the risk. If I do not kill this cancer it will destroy my business. ‘Alex dries his hands, tosses the towel on the floor.
Burn this trash.

Street running et full tilt, weaving through, over and ar parked cars. He bisects @ homeless camp. . Street approaches a large concrete fortress -- LAPD CENTR STATION -- flashes his ID to the GUARDS. Vaults the concr barriers without slowing.
Quite an armada of vehicles. Suburbans. Pick-ups. Unmarke cars. Two SWAT TRUCKS are on stand-by to serve as mobile armories and command posts.
Crammed into an out of the way corner
An amazing essortment of SWAT gear ranging from the munda to the exotic. There are helmets, radios, vests and armor A myriad of tools. Office supplies. Lockers of flashbang grenades and ammo.

Flush from his run, in a police uniform that suggests off comfort, he pours hot coffee in a sports bottle. Adds cre sugar. A fistful of vitamins. Some protein powder. Shakes it. He slurps the concoction as he settles into a desk swamped with stacks of paperwork. Street has a shrine to better days --° Shooting trophies, SWAT Olympics trophies. Photos of him on the SWAT Team.

A dozen SWAT COPS in crisp fatigues stampede out a briefi room. BOXER and TJ, both young proven Swat officers, cros to the cage. sO Hey, Boxer. ‘ : BOXER Morning, Street.

Hondo doesn't need a trigger happy has-been. Street glares, if looks could kill. “STREET Keep talking shit, TJ. To (to Boxer) Be honest. Would you want Street rescuing your grandmother?
Sure. Street's good. (@ Hondo approaches the cage. TJ and Boxer grab the ammo . and cross to the Suburbans. Now it's just Hondo and Str (CONTINUED)

Sergeant Hondo.. Hondo gives Street a look.
Get used to it, you're a supervisor now. Sew those on yourself? Street points at the brand new Sergeant's patches sewn on his sleeves.
Last night.. They're finally making me grow up, I guess. Street rolls up his sleeve, revealing shiny scars where h shattered arm was pinned and braced. Street makes a fist.
Look at that. All healed now, a hundred percent. Passed my physical. Honde, I am on. My skills are razor sharp. I'm better than I was two years ago. Hondo looks at Street.

Saddle up and move out! I wanna shoot guns and break shit. The SWAT Cops mount their vehicles. A flurry of activity they pull out. Street watches them depart from behind wire mesh. It's quiet again. Street looks around his cage, as if realizing for the ten thousandth time:
This sucks.
